items.title: Issue with openid dependency
items.body:
Hello there,

I am facing a weird issue with openid that seems to be fixed a long time ago. To be specific I am having the same issue as #21. The weird thing is that I have been using Django social for more than 2 years in the same project and had no issues. Not it suddenly appeared when I just rebuilt the docker container.

### What I have tried
* Use python:3.7 image
* Use python:3.8 image
* Run natively on python 3.7 and 3.8
* Rebuild the project
* Rebuild the virtualenv
* Looked at [social_core](https://github.com/python-social-auth/social-core) for changes but the latest version is [3.3.3](https://github.com/python-social-auth/social-core/releases/tag/3.3.3) and was published on Apr 3rd. ( I have definitely rebuilt the project a couple of times)
* Looked for changes here on this project. I noticed a couple of version bumps but requirements have not been touched since 3 years ago.

### Traceback
As you can see in the traceback the problem starts on `.models` imports here
https://github.com/python-social-auth/social-app-django/blob/236234bac903887fb02386b535c30211119a62a0/social_django/models.py#L11-L13


but leads to python-openid [`__init__`](https://github.com/openid/python-openid/blob/f7e13536f0d1828d3cef5ae7a7b55cabadff37fc/openid/__init__.py#L47-L55) file

https://github.com/openid/python-openid/blob/f7e13536f0d1828d3cef5ae7a7b55cabadff37fc/openid/__init__.py#L47-L55 

```py
  File "/home/dstrants/projects/ypostirizo/venv/lib/python3.8/site-packages/social_django/models.py", line 11, in <module>
    from .storage import DjangoUserMixin, DjangoAssociationMixin, \
  File "/home/dstrants/projects/ypostirizo/venv/lib/python3.8/site-packages/social_django/storage.py", line 9, in <module>
    from social_core.storage import UserMixin, AssociationMixin, NonceMixin, \
  File "/home/dstrants/projects/ypostirizo/venv/lib/python3.8/site-packages/social_core/storage.py", line 12, in <module>
    from openid.association import Association as OpenIdAssociation
  File "/home/dstrants/projects/ypostirizo/venv/lib/python3.8/site-packages/openid/__init__.py", line 52, in <module>
    if len(version_info) != 3:
TypeError: object of type 'map' has no len()
```

What I do not get so far is: _is it supposed to include `puthon-openid` or just `python3-openid`, cause if I try to just remove `python-openid` it is not working and `python3-openid` is looking for it_

items.title: Google oauth - approval_prompt: "auto" not a valid parameter value
items.body:
Hello, 
 I have just came across an error (bug perhaps), that in my Django application, usage of the Google social auth login produces and error:

```
Error 400: invalid_request
Invalid parameter value for approval_prompt: 'auto' is not valid
```

My usage of the social auth is creating a link in a template:

`{% url 'social:begin' 'google-oauth2' %}`

No additional special configuration options, nothing. 
I suppose that this was due to some Google side change, because yesterday evening, everything worked fine.

I needed this library in a project, and it would make things a lot easier for me if there's a new release.

items.title: Twitch API Update
items.body:
Twitch API v3 has been shutted down in September, so that flow doesn't work anymore. It raises an error like:
`requests.exceptions.HTTPError: 410 Client Error: Gone for url: https://api.twitch.tv/kraken/user/?oauth_token=fg2t36gq2dwq0lsc8e9hx8lgfju32g`

There is a workaround if you change the line 29 of the twitch.py backends file:
` params={'oauth_token': access_token}` to `params={'oauth_token': access_token, 'api_version': 5}`
([More info here](https://dev.twitch.tv/docs/v5/guides/migration/#default-api-version))

But this workaround is not official and will be deprecated soon too, they recommend to migrate to the new [Twitch API](https://dev.twitch.tv/docs/api/)

items.title: TypeError: pipeline() got multiple values for argument 'pipeline_index'
items.body:
```
TypeError: pipeline() got multiple values for argument 'pipeline_index'
  File "tulip/social/views.py", line 77, in complete
    **kwargs
  File "social_core/actions.py", line 39, in do_complete
    user = backend.continue_pipeline(partial)
  File "social_core/backends/base.py", line 201, in continue_pipeline
    **partial.kwargs)
  File "social_django/strategy.py", line 107, in authenticate
    return authenticate(*args, **kwargs)
  File "django/contrib/auth/__init__.py", line 73, in authenticate
    user = backend.authenticate(request, **credentials)
  File "social_core/backends/base.py", line 80, in authenticate
    return self.pipeline(pipeline, *args, **kwargs)
```

# mock code that reproduces the bug

```python
from django.http import HttpRequest

def continue_pipeline():
    return django_strategy_authenticate(
        "backend", pipeline_index=12
    )


def django_strategy_authenticate(backend, *args, **kwargs):
    kwargs['backend'] = backend
    return django_contrib_auth_authenticate(*args, **kwargs)


def django_contrib_auth_authenticate(request=None, **credentials):
    """
    If the given credentials are valid, return a User object.
    """
    baseauth_authenticate(request, **credentials)


def baseauth_authenticate(*args, **kwargs):
    args, kwargs = clean_authenticate_args(*args, **kwargs)

    return baseauth_pipeline("pipeline", *args, **kwargs)

def clean_authenticate_args(*args, **kwargs):
    """Cleanup request argument if present, which is passed to
    authenticate as for Django 1.11"""
    if len(args) > 0 and isinstance(args[0], HttpRequest):
        kwargs['request'], args = args[0], args[1:]
    return args, kwargs

def baseauth_pipeline(pipeline, pipeline_index=0, *args, **kwargs):
    # we never get here
    print("hey it actually worked")


continue_pipeline()

```

# suspects

* `django.contrib.auth.authenticate` is defaulting the `request` kwarg to `None` because it's not provided by the `DjangoStrategy`.
* This means that `DjangoStrategy.clean_authenticate_args` doesn't remove the request from `args` to put it into `kwargs`.
* which in turn means that `BaseAuth.authenticate` passes the request (`None`) as the second arg to `BaseAuth.pipeline`, which is supposed to be `pipeline_index`
* and since `pipeline_index` is _also_ passed as a keyword arg, this raises a `TypeError`

# versions and lineage

```
Django==2.1.11
social-auth-app-django==3.1.0
social-auth-core==3.2.0
```

moved from python-social-auth/social-core#392 once I figured out where the problem lies.
might be related to: #57, #77.

items.title: ImportError: No module named 'jose' building 2.1.0
items.body:
Hi,

We've just run into this issue when building our images this morning. 
```
 Traceback (most recent call last):
  File "/root/project/embed_service/design/tests/test_admin.py", line 93, in setUp
    self.client.force_login(self.user)
  File "/usr/local/lib/python3.5/dist-packages/django/test/client.py", line 609, in force_login
    backend = get_backend()
  File "/usr/local/lib/python3.5/dist-packages/django/test/client.py", line 605, in get_backend
    backend = load_backend(backend_path)
  File "/usr/local/lib/python3.5/dist-packages/django/contrib/auth/__init__.py", line 21, in load_backend
    return import_string(path)()
  File "/usr/local/lib/python3.5/dist-packages/django/utils/module_loading.py", line 17, in import_string
    module = import_module(module_path)
  File "/usr/lib/python3.5/importlib/__init__.py", line 126, in import_module
    return _bootstrap._gcd_import(name[level:], package, level)
  File "<frozen importlib._bootstrap>", line 986, in _gcd_import
  File "<frozen importlib._bootstrap>", line 969, in _find_and_load
  File "<frozen importlib._bootstrap>", line 958, in _find_and_load_unlocked
  File "<frozen importlib._bootstrap>", line 673, in _load_unlocked
  File "<frozen importlib._bootstrap_external>", line 673, in exec_module
  File "<frozen importlib._bootstrap>", line 222, in _call_with_frames_removed
  File "/usr/local/lib/python3.5/dist-packages/unauth/backends.py", line 3, in <module>
    from social_core.backends.google_openidconnect import GoogleOpenIdConnect
  File "/usr/local/lib/python3.5/dist-packages/social_core/backends/google_openidconnect.py", line 5, in <module>
    from .open_id_connect import OpenIdConnectAuth
  File "/usr/local/lib/python3.5/dist-packages/social_core/backends/open_id_connect.py", line 5, in <module>
    from jose import jwk, jwt
ImportError: No module named 'jose'
```

We have a wrapper for `social-auth-app-django` and we currently use the version `2.1.0`. 

For that version [the requeriments](https://github.com/python-social-auth/social-app-django/blob/2.1.0/requirements.txt) allow to install `social-auth-core==2.0.0` which in [this commit](https://github.com/python-social-auth/social-core/commit/1e6dbf91ed6d798737a237e399c51f1655270440) is changing to introduce `python-jose`.

Probably constraining the use of `social-auth-core` for older versions of `social-auth-app-django` may resolve it.

items.title: Error "Incorrect padding" when using OpenID
items.body:
Initially reported as https://github.com/python-social-auth/social-core/issues/180

On Python 3, the secret obtained from the remote server might be saved with the binary prefix "b'secret'" in the association.secret fields, which then lead later to the "Incorrect padding" exception when trying to use that secret.

Replacing `assoc.secret = base64.encodestring(association.secret)` by `assoc.secret = base64.encodestring(association.secret).decode()` in `storage.py` seems to solve the issue.

############################ ERROR ##################################

items.title: Documentation needs fixing. Partial pipeline example. AttributeError 'User' object has no attribute 'profile'
items.body:
I'm getting an error when trying to extend the pipeline following the documentation at: http://python-social-auth.readthedocs.io/en/latest/pipeline.html#extending-the-pipeline

I use Django version 1.11.4 and python 3.6
I get the error: 

```
> Exception Type: | AttributeError
> 'User' object has no attribute 'profile'
```

when trying to run the code
`profile = user.get_profile()`

After reading this:
https://stackoverflow.com/a/21734033/6862530 

I read the django documentation here:
http://django.readthedocs.io/en/latest/topics/auth/customizing.html#django.contrib.auth.models.AbstractBaseUser 

and ended up fixing the error by using using  this:
`profile = user.get_username()`

items.title: Set JSONField's default to callable
items.body:
Current implementation is `kwargs.setdefault('default', {})`.
This makes all the model instances share same object reference. So, updating one object's data effects all of the objects and will result in data corruption.
changing to `kwargs.setdefault('default', dict)` will fix the issue.

items.title: ``expires_in`` and OAuth2 RFC
items.body:
Hello, 

[OAuth2 RFC](https://tools.ietf.org/html/rfc6749#section-5.1) provides the following information on the successful response: 

- ``access_token`` (REQUIRED)
- ``token_type`` (REQUIRED)
- ``expires_in`` (RECOMMENDED; The lifetime in seconds of the access token. If omitted, the authorization server SHOULD provide the expiration time via other means or document the default value.)
- ``refresh_token``(OPTIONAL)
- ``scope`` (OPTIONAL, if identical to the scope requested by the client; otherwise, REQUIRED.)

Having this in mind some parameters could be common in the extra data for OAuth2:

- ``access_token`` 
- ``token_type`` 
- ``expires_in`` 

Having this in mind I I purpose that in ``BaseOAuth2`` we start having something like this: ``EXPIRES_IN_KEY = 'expires_in'`` and ``EXPIRES_IN_DEFAULT = None``. 

This can be used in [extra_data()](https://github.com/python-social-auth/social-core/blob/master/social_core/backends/oauth.py#L361) to save the lifetime in seconds of the access token complementing the  ``auth_time`` and making it possible to use [access_token expired()](https://github.com/python-social-auth/social-core/blob/9fb7a06a0618aa88d62b980392f77b5a5f91f98f/social_core/storage.py#L94) at all times (for OAuth2).

PS: Is there any reason why currently the ``expires_in`` is ``expire`` in most backends and also the name used for [expiration_timedelta()](https://github.com/python-social-auth/social-core/blob/9fb7a06a0618aa88d62b980392f77b5a5f91f98f/social_core/storage.py#L59)?
In my opinion, this method should be changed from ``expires`` to ``expires_in`` to comply with the RFC and backward compatible assured.

This discussion started in  [StackOverflow](http://stackoverflow.com/q/41466731/4470542) and I think it should be continued here.

items.title: Allow For Configuration of Redirect URI
items.body:
## Subtitle:  Don't build redirect_uri based on current URL if x is set 

This MIGHT be a no-op, but after a few hours of poking I couldn't find a solution in the current config. I might just be dense about Django internals; if so, I apologize. 

### Scenario
   Nginx proxy/static resource server (docker container: my_proxy)
   Django app in the backend configured (docker app: my_portal)

When a user hits "awesome.example.com/login/github", `my_proxy` receives it and relays it to the `my_portal`. The Django app then redirects over to Github for the authentication flow, but it uses the url name it sees on the HTTP request from the proxy: `http://my_portal/complete/github/redirect_state/...`. 

Obviously Github doesn't handle this well after I authenticate on their end, when it redirects back to my top-level domain,with this value I get a `redirect_uri` error: 

```
Authentication failed: The redirect_uri MUST match the registered callback URL for this application.
```

### Work Around
To work around this I think I can rewriting the headers on the proxy from Nginx to use the top-level domain host that I'm working on (i.e. forwarding `awesome.example.com` to `my_portal` instead of addressing it as `my_portal`). But I believe this prevents (or at least increasingly restricts) me from spinning up multiple Django app backends to serve the application. 

### Ask
Being able to name my application servers whatever internal name I want, but configure the redirection URL would allow me to keep. 

The idea that I think works is allowing the hostname to be overwritten by a setting in Django. I'm bad at naming such things, but `SOCIAL_APP_FQDN` or `REDIRECTION_BASE_URL` would let me configure the plugin to generate `redirect_uri` values that match my app domain, rather than a container host or internal server IP/FQDN. 

### Alternatives
The answer could very well be "this overcomplicates the social stack" or "nobody does it the way you're describing you madperson". If anyone has any guidance or feedback here that I could work into some documentation I would appreciate it!

items.title: Migration broken from 0.2.19 (and older)
items.body:
This is followup for #16. 

With #25 the migration from 0.2.20 and 0.2.21 is working fine, however users upgrading from 0.2.19 and older will still end up with error.

It can end up with error described in #16:

```
KeyError: u"Migration social_django.0002_add_related_name dependencies reference nonexistent parent node (u'social_django', u'0001_initial')"
```

Or it can pop up as error while validating relations (see https://github.com/WeblateOrg/weblate/issues/1344):

```
ValueError: The field accounts.VerifiedEmail.social was declared with a lazy reference to 'social_django.usersocialauth', but app 'social_django' isn't installed.
```

The problem is that Django does not see the old migrations as they are just half applied (due to missing `social_auth` ones):

```
manage.py showmigrations
...
social_django
 [ ] 0005_auto_20160727_2333 (1 squashed migrations)
 [ ] 0006_partial
...
```

This is what is stored in the database:

items.title: Crashes with Django 1.11
items.body:
With Django 1.11 you get following crash:

```
  File "/home/nijel/work/weblate/django/contrib/auth/__init__.py", line 86, in authenticate
    user = backend.authenticate(*args, **credentials)
  File "/home/nijel/work/weblate/social_core/backends/base.py", line 78, in authenticate
    return self.pipeline(pipeline, *args, **kwargs)
  File "/home/nijel/work/weblate/social_core/backends/base.py", line 81, in pipeline
    out = self.run_pipeline(pipeline, pipeline_index, *args, **kwargs)
  File "/home/nijel/work/weblate/social_core/backends/base.py", line 104, in run_pipeline
    out['pipeline_index'] = pipeline_index + idx
TypeError: unsupported operand type(s) for +: 'NoneType' and 'int'
```

The problem is that Django now adds positional request parameter to authenticate call and social auth accepts it as pipeline, see Django code for more details how it is done: https://github.com/django/django/blob/stable/1.11.x/django/contrib/auth/__init__.py#L69

items.title: How to convert code to access_token
items.body:
Hello! I do a REST API to authenticate via social networks.

If I login via `/login/backend/` Backend-class will receive parameter `code` and make a request to `ACCESS_TOKEN_URL` to get the `access_token`. Normal behavior for the Authorization Code Flow.

But in the [FAQ](http://python-social-auth-docs.readthedocs.io/en/latest/use_cases.html#signup-by-oauth-access-token) you propose to use `request.backend.do_auth(access_token)` for the REST API. But I have no access_token! My client has only `code`! How do I convert a `code` in the `access_token` using the methods of class `request.backend`?

items.title: New method in AbstractUserSocialAuth
items.body:
New method suggestion for AbstractUserSocialAuth.

Objective: Get an always updated access_token easily.

Something like this:

     from social_django.utils import load_strategy
     ...
    @classmethod
    def get_access_token(cls, provider, uid):
        if (cls.extra_data['auth_time'] + cls.extra_data['expires_in']) <= int(time.time()):
            strategy = load_strategy()
            social.refresh_token(strategy)
        return self.extra_data['access_token']


I haven't tested it, nor think about exceptions, but I can do it and do fork request. Do you agree with adding this method?
